utterance:
Hé! Ah! Oh, Honorine! Yes; the first
of the month, and affairs-affairs to be trans
acted.
speaker: the General

utterance:
In a moment, husband.
In a moment.
speaker: Honorine

utterance:
But he should be here now. It is the
first of the month, it is nine o'clock, I am
ready; he should be here.
speaker: the General

utterance: It is not yet nine o'clock, husband.
speaker: Honorine

utterance:
Not yet nine! Not yet nine! Am I
not up? Am I not dressed? Have I not
breakfasted before nine?
speaker: the General

utterance: That is so, husband. That is so.
speaker: Honorine

utterance:
It is getting worse and worse every day.
I tell you, Honorine, Pompey must be dis
charged. He is worthless. He is trifling.
Discharge him! Discharge him! Do not
have him about! Chase him out of the
yard! Chase him as soon as he makes his
appearance! Do you hear, Honorine?
speaker: the General

utterance:
You must have a little patience, hus
band.
speaker: Honorine

utterance:
Patience! Patience! Patience is the
invention of dullards and sluggards. In a
well-regulated world there should be no need
of such a thing as patience. Patience should
be punished as a crime, or at least as a
breach of the peace. Wherever patience
is found police investigation should be made
as for smallpox. Patience! Patience! I
never heard the word-I assure you, I
never heard the word in Paris. What do
you think would be said there to the mes
senger who craved patience of you? Oh,
they know too well in Paris-a rataplan
from the walking-stick on his back, that
would be the answer; and a, My good
fellow, we are not hiring professors of pa
tience, but legs.
speaker: the General

utterance:
But, husband, you must remember we do
not hire Pompey. He only does it to oblige
us, out of his kindness.
speaker: Honorine

utterance:
Oblige us! Oblige me! Kindness! A
negro oblige me! Kind to me! That is it;
that is it. That is the way to talk under the
new régime. It is favor, and oblige, and edu
cation, and monsieur, and madame, now. What
child's play to call this a country-a govern
ment! I would not be surprised ”—jumping
to his next position on this ever-recurring first
of the month theme-
speaker: the General

utterance:
I would not be sur
prised if Pompey has failed to find the letter
in the box. How do I know that the mail
has not been tampered with? From day to
day I expect to hear it. What is to prevent?
Who is to interpose? The honesty of the of
ficials? Honesty of the officials-that is good!
What a farce-honesty of officials! That is
evidently what has happened. The thought
has not occurred to me in vain. Pompey has
gone. He has not found the letter, and-
well; that is the end.
speaker: the General

utterance: And why not Journel?
speaker: the General

utterance:
Journel himself? You think he is above it,
hé? You think Journel would not do such a
thing? Ha! your simplicity, Honorine
Honorine-your
simplicity is incredible. It is miraculous. I
tell you, I have known the Journels, from
father to son, for-yes, for seventy-five years.
Was not his grandfather the overseer on my
father's plantation? I was not five years old
when I began to know the Journels. And
this fellow, I know him better than he knows
himself. I know him as well as God knows
him. I have made up my mind. I have made
it up carefully that the first time that letter
fails on the first of the month I shall have
Journel arrested as a thief. I shall land him
in the penitentiary. What! You think I shall
submit to have my mail tampered with by a
Journel? Their contents appropriated? What!
You think there was no coincidence in Jour
nel's offering me his post-office box just the
month-just the month, before those letters
began to arrive? You think he did not have
some inkling of them? Mark my words,
Honorine, he did-by some of his subterra
nean methods. And all these five years he
has been arranging his plans-that is all.
He was arranging theft, which no doubt has
been consummated to-day. Oh, I have re
gretted it-I assure you I have regretted it,
that I did not promptly reject his proposition,
that, in fact, I ever had anything to do with
the fellow.
speaker: the General

utterance: Bah!
speaker: Mademoiselle Idalie

utterance:
But you know, Louise, papa
39
-
would never have consented, never, never-
poor papa! Indeed, I should never have
asked him; it would only have been one hu-
miliation more for him, poor papa! So it
was well he was dead, if it was God's will for
it to be. Of course I had my dreams, like
everybody. I was so blonde, so blonde, and
so small; it seemed like a law I should marry
a brun, a tall, handsome brun, with a mus-
tache and a fine barytone voice. That was
how I always arranged it, and you will
laugh-but a large, large house, and num-
bers of servants, and a good cook, but a su-
perlatively good cuisine, and wine and all
that, and long, trailing silk dresses, and the-
ater every night, and voyages to Europe, and
-well, everything God had to give, in fact.
You know, I get that from papa, wanting
everything God has to give! Poor papa!
It seemed to me I was to meet him at any
time, my handsome brun. I used to look for
him positively on my way to school, and back
home again, and whenever I would think of
him I would try and walk so prettily, and
look so pretty! Mon Dieu! I was not ten
years old yet! And afterward it was only for
that that I went into society. What should
41
girls go into society for otherwise but to meet
their brun or their blond? Do
Do you think it
is amusing, to economize and economize, and
sew and sew, just to go to a party to dance?
No! I assure you, I went into society only
for that; and I do not believe what girls say
-they go into society only for that too.
"You know at school how we used to tirer
la bonne aventure. Well, every time he was
not brun, riche, avenant, Jules, or Raoul, or
Guy, I simply would not accept it, but would
go on drawing until I obtained what I wanted.
As I tell you, I thought it was my destiny.
And when I would try with a flower to see if
he loved me,-Il m'aime, un peu, beaucoup,
passionément, pas du tout,—if it were pas du
tout, I would always throw the flower away,
and begin tearing off the leaves from another
one immediately. Passionément was what I
wanted, and I always got it in the end.
'But papa, poor papa, he never knew any-
thing of that, of course. He would get furi-
speaker: Mimi

utterance: But do not be a fool, Mimi,
speaker: Clementine

utterance:
Am I God? Can I do miracles? Or
must I humiliate your papa?
speaker: Clementine

utterance:
Clementine!' I would cry, that your papa does not
make money for his family.' That was true.
speaker: Clementine

utterance:
Come, we will take a glass of anisette, and
talk of something else your trip, your
family. No? no? You are only asking me
out of politeness! You are so aimable, so
kind. Well, if you are not ennuyée — in
fact, I want to tell you. It was too long to
write, and I detest a pen. To me there is
no instrument of torture like a pen.
speaker: Mimi

utterance: Is this the miracle chapel, little boy?'
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Yes, ma'am; yes.
speaker: the little boy

utterance: Here. Take this -
speaker: the narrator

utterance: I ain't begging.
speaker: the little boy

utterance:
What are you looking at so through the
fence?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Just looking.
speaker: the little boy

utterance: Is there anything to see inside?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: I can't see nothing. I'm blind,
speaker: the little boy

utterance:
Come, won't you tell me how this came
to be a miracle chapel?
speaker: the narrator

utterance:
Oh, ma'am, it was a poor widow woman who
come here with her baby that was a-dying,
and she prayed to the Virgin Mary, and the
Virgin Mary made the baby live
speaker: the little boy

utterance: Did you know the widow woman?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: How do you know it?
speaker: the narrator

utterance:
That was what they told me.
And they
told me, the birds all begun to sing at once,
and the flowers all lighted up like the sun
was shining on them. They seed her. And
she come down the walk, and through the
gate,
speaker: the little boy

utterance:
And that is why you stand here-to see
her, too?
speaker: the narrator

utterance:
They seed her, and they ain't got no
eyes.
speaker: the little boy

utterance: Have you no mother?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Ain't never had no mother.
speaker: the little boy

utterance:
Would that count, ma'am?
Would that count? The little baby that was
dying - yes, ma'am, it had a mother; and
it's the mothers that come here constant
with their children; I sometimes hear 'em
dragging them in by the hand.
speaker: the little boy

utterance: How long have you been coming here?
speaker: the narrator

utterance:
Ever since the first time I heard it,
ma'am.
speaker: the little boy

utterance:
They seed her- I might see her ef— ef
I could see her once- ef- ef I could see
anything once.
speaker: the little boy

utterance:
She might see me.
She can't pass through this gate without see-
ing me; and-and-ef she seed me-and
I did n't even see her—oh, I'm so tired of
being blind!
speaker: the little boy

utterance: Did you never go inside to pray?
speaker: the narrator

utterance:
No, ma'am. Does that count, too? The
little baby did n't pray, the flowers did n't
go inside, nor the birds. And they say the
birds broke out singing all at once, and the
flowers shined, like the sun was shining on
'em like the sun was shining in 'em,
speaker: the little boy

utterance: Where do you live?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: What do you live on?
speaker: the narrator

utterance: Eh, Anne Marie, my girl, this time we have caught it!
speaker: Jeanne Marie

utterance: Whose ticket?
speaker: Anne Marie

utterance: But your ticket, Coton-Maï!
speaker: Anne Marie

utterance: Where? Give it here! Give it here!
speaker: Anne Marie

utterance: Ill luck! Coton-Maï! Ill luck! There's a way to turn ill luck!
speaker: Anne Marie

utterance: Coton-Maï!
speaker: Jeanne Marie

utterance: But I must see the old woman smile again over her good luck.
speaker: Jeanne Marie

utterance: Adorine! Adorine!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Zepherin! Zepherin!
speaker: Adorine Mérionaux

utterance: Where's little Mammy?
speaker: newest inmates

utterance: Oh, little Mammy! little Mammy! Such a misery in my head [or my back, or my stomach]! Can't you help me, little Mammy?
speaker: newest inmates

utterance: Our time does n't come just as often as it does come.
speaker: little Mammy

utterance: Buy me, master!
speaker: others

utterance: Buy me, mistress!
speaker: others

utterance: You'll see how I can work, master!
speaker: others

utterance: You'll never be sorry, mistress!
speaker: others

utterance: Oh, madame!
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Ah, madame!
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Quelle ivresse!
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Quelle horreur!
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Pourquoi ces larmes?
speaker: Leonore

utterance: I have always had the temptation, but I have always resisted it. Now, it may be your spring weather, your birds, your flowers, your sky—and your children in the streets. The longing came over me yesterday: I thought of it on the stage, I thought of it afterward-it was better than sleeping; and this morning
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: I was determined. I gave up, I made inquiry, I was sent to you. Would it be possible? Would there be any place in any of your asylums, in any of your charitable institutions, for me? I would ask nothing but my clothes and food, and very little of that; the recompense would be the children-the little girl children,
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Think! Never to have held a child in my arms more than a moment, never to have felt a child's arms about my neck! Never to have known a child! Born on a stage, my mother born on a stage!
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Pardon, madam. You see how I repeat. And you must be very wearied hearing about me. But I could be their nurse and their servant. I would bathe and dress them, play with them, teach them their prayers; and when they are sick they would see no difference. They would not know but what their mother was there!
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: And I would sing to them-no! no! nothing from the stage; little songs and lullabys I have picked up traveling around, and, little things I have composed myself-little things that I thought children would like to hear some day.
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Their little arms, their little faces, their little lips! And in an asylum there would be so many of them! When they cried and were in trouble I would take them in my lap, and I would say to them, with all sorts of tenderness—
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: And my heart hungers to commence right here, now, at once! It seems to me I cannot wait. Ah, madam, no more stage, no more opera!
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: As I said, it may be your beautiful spring, your flowers, your birds, and your numbers of children. I have always loved that place most where there are most children; and you have more children here than I ever saw anywhere. Children are so beautiful! It is strange, is it not, when you consider my life and my rearing?
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: They say you have much to do with asylums here.
speaker: the dugazon of the opera troupe

utterance: Good-by, my dear
speaker: the captain

utterance: Be a good little girl-
speaker: the captain

utterance: Captain! Captain!
speaker: unnamed

utterance: The cross, and the name of the convent.
speaker: unnamed

utterance: I have brought her to see you. You were so kind-and she is so quiet, so still, all the time, I thought it would do her a pleasure.
speaker: the mother of the little convent girl

utterance: She don't go nowhere, she don't do nothing but make her crochet and her prayers, so I thought I would bring her for a little visit of How d' ye do' to you.
speaker: the mother of the little convent girl

utterance: My dear, do you know there is really such a thing as existence without a carriage and horses?
speaker: the old lady

utterance: I assure you it is perfectly new to me to find that an opera-box is not a necessity. It is a luxury. In theory one can really never tell the distinction between luxuries and necessities.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: How absurd! At one time I thought hair was given us only to furnish a profession to hair-dressers; just as we wear artificial flowers to support the flower-makers.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Upon my word, it is not uninteresting. There is always some haute nouveauté in economy. The ways of depriving one's self are infinite. There is wine, now.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Not own your residence! As soon not own your tomb as your residence! My mama used to scream that in my ears. According to her, it was not comme il faut to board or live in a rented house. How little she knew!
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Fat. I am living off my fat, as bears do in winter. In truth, I remind myself of an animal in more ways than one.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: It is nothing.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Made-to-order feet learning to walk in ready-made shoes: that is all. One's feet, after all, are the most unintelligent part of one's body.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Tea, you know, is so detestable that the very worst is hardly worse than the very best; while coffee is so perfect that the smallest shade of impurity is not to be tolerated. The truly economical, I observe, always drink tea.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Comforts! Luxuries!
speaker: the old lady

utterance: And friends! You say right.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Comfort!
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Bouillon! A good five-cent bouillon. Luxury!
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Luxury!
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Did you ever lie in your bed at night and dream of new cotton sheets? Comfort! Luxury! I should say so! And friends! My dear, look!
speaker: the old lady

utterance: Friends! All friends-friends for fifteen years. Ah, yes, indeed! We are all glad―elated in fact. As you say. I am restored.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: What does this extraordinary display light mean?
speaker: my aunt

utterance: It looks like the kingdom of heaven in here! Jules! Jules!
speaker: my aunt

utterance: come and put out some of the light!
speaker: my aunt

utterance: But what do you mean now, Jules?
speaker: my aunt

utterance: Pardon, madame, it is an accident. I thought there was one still lighted.
speaker: Jules

utterance: An accident! An accident! Do you think I hire you to perform accidents for me?
speaker: my aunt

utterance: You are just through telling me that it was accident made you give me both soup and gumbo for dinner to-day.
speaker: my aunt

utterance: But accidents can always happen, madame,
speaker: Jules

utterance: What will madame have for her dinner to-morrow
speaker: Jules

utterance: Do I ever give orders for one dinner, with the other one still on my lips?
speaker: my aunt

utterance: I only asked madame; there is no harm in asking.
speaker: Jules

utterance: Oh, madame, here is Mr. Horace. Shall I let him in?
speaker: Jules

utterance: Idiot! Every Wednesday you ask me that question, and every Wednesday I answer the same way. Don't you think I could tell you when not to let him in without your asking?
speaker: my aunt

utterance: Oh, well, madame, one never knows; it is always safe to ask.
speaker: Jules

utterance: Jules! Jules! You have left that front door unlocked again!
speaker: my aunt

utterance: Excuse me, Jules did not leave the front door unlocked. It was locked when I rang, and he locked it again most carefully after letting me in. I have been standing outside all the while the gas was being extinguished and relighted.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Ah, very well, then. And what is the news?
speaker: my aunt

utterance: I never hear any news, you know. She [nodding toward me] goes out, but she never learns anything. She is as stupid to-night as an empty bottle.
speaker: my aunt

utterance: Bah! lose a game for a card!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Jules! Jules!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Jules! Jules!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: But where have you been? Here I have been raising the house a half-hour, calling you. You have been in the street. I am sure you have been in the street.
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Madame is very much mistaken. When madame forbids me to go into the street, I do not go into the street. I was in the kitchen; I had fallen asleep. What does madame desire?
speaker: Jules

utterance: What is this I hear? Fresh mushrooms in the market!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Eh, madame?
speaker: Jules

utterance: Fresh mushrooms in the market, and you have not brought me any!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Madame, there are fresh mushrooms everywhere in the market,
speaker: Jules

utterance: Everybody is eating them—
speaker: Jules

utterance: Old Pomponnette only this morning offered me a plate, piled up high, for ten cents.
speaker: Jules

utterance: Idiot! Why did you not buy them?
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: If madame had said so; but madame did not say so. Madame said, 'Soup, Jules; carrots, rice,'
speaker: Jules

utterance: And the gumbo?
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: I have explained that that was an accident. Madame said 'Soup,'
speaker: Jules

utterance: madame never once said mushrooms.
speaker: Jules

utterance: But how could I know there were mushrooms in the market? Do I go to market?
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: That is it!
speaker: Jules

utterance: If you had told me there were mushrooms in the market-
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Why did not madame ask me? If madame had asked me, surely I would have told madame. Yesterday Cæsar brought them to the door-a whole bucketful for twenty-five cents. I had to shut the door in his face to get rid of him,
speaker: Jules

utterance: And you brought me yesterday those detestable peas!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Ah,
speaker: Jules

utterance: madame told me to buy what I saw. I saw peas. I bought them.
speaker: Jules

utterance: Well, understand now, once for all: whenever you see mushrooms, no matter what I ordered, you buy them. Do you hear?
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: No, madame. Surely I cannot buy mushrooms unless madame orders them. Madame's disposition is too quick.
speaker: Jules

utterance: But I do order them. Stupid! I do order them. I tell you to buy them every day.
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: And if there are none in the market every day?
speaker: Jules

utterance: Go away! Get out of my sight! I do not want to see you. Ah, it is unendurable! I must-I must get rid of him!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: It is as beautiful as the past,
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Hein?
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Ah, bah! Speak louder! One would suppose you had some secret to tell. What secrets can there be at our age?
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Yes, yes, what secrets can there be at our age?
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: When that was painted, Josephine-
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Ah, at that time we were all nymphs, and you all demigods.
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: Demigods and nymphs, yes; but there was one among us who was a god with you all.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Remember?
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: A woman's memory! When I think of a woman's memory-in fact, I do not like to think of a woman's memory. One can intrude in imagination into many places; but a woman's memory—
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: And a man's memory! It is not there that I either would penetrate, my friend. A man-
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: That you should marry — seemed natural, inevitable, at the time.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: But the natural — the inevitable-do we not sometimes, I wonder, perform them as Jules does his accidents?
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Ah, do not talk about that idiot! An idiot born and bred! I won't have him about me! He is a monstrosity! I tell his grandmother that every day when she comes to comb me. What a farce—what a ridiculous farce comfortable existence has become with us! Fresh mushrooms in market, and bring me carrots!
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: One cannot tell. It seems so at the time. We like to think it so; it makes it easier. And yet, looking back on our future as we once looked forward to it-
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Eh! but who wants to look back on it, my friend? Who in the world wants to look back on it? We have done our future, we have performed it, if you will. Our future! It is like the dinners we have eaten; of course we cannot remember the good without becoming exasperated over the bad: but- since we cannot beat the cooks, we must submit to fate,
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: At sixteen and twenty-one it is hard to realize that one is arranging one's life to last until sixty, seventy, forever,
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: When I look back to that time,I see nothing but lights and flowers, I hear nothing but music and laughter; and all-lights and flowers and music and laughter-seem to meet in this room, where we met so often to arrange our - inevitabilities.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Josephine, how beautiful you were!
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: They used to say, the men used to say that your beauty was irresistible. None ever withstood you. None ever could.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: It was only their excuse, perhaps; we could not tell at the time; we cannot tell even now when we think about it. They said then, talking as men talk over such things, that you were the only one who could remain yourself under the circumstances; you were the only one who could know, who could will, under the circumstances. It was their theory; men can have only theories about such things.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: How beautiful she was!
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: You there, he there, she there, I there.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: She was, in truth, what we men called her then; it was her eyes that first suggested it- Myosotis, the little blue flower, the forget-me-not. It suited her better than her own name. We always called her that among ourselves. How beautiful she was!
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: What there is in blue eyes, light hair, and a fragile form to impress one, I cannot tell; but for us men it seems to me it is blue-eyed, light-haired, and fragile-formed women that are the hardest to forget.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: The less easy to forget,
speaker: Madame B———

utterance: They are the women that attach themselves in one's memory. If necessary to keep from being forgotten, they come back into one's dreams. And as life rolls on, one wonders about them,—'Is she happy? Is she miserable? Goes life well or ill with her?'
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: And there is always a pang when, as one is so wondering, the response comes,—that is, the certainty in one's heart responds,—'She is miserable, and life goes ill with her.' Then, if ever, men envy the power of God.
speaker: Mr. Horace

utterance: Such women should not be unhappy; they are too fragile, to
speaker: Mr. Horace

speaker: Pupasse

utterance: Quelle injustice! Quelle injustice!
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: Young ladies! But what does this mean?
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: It's Pupasse, madame! It's Pupasse who made us laugh!
speaker: the students

utterance: It's that Pupasse! It's that vilaine Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: Oh, but take it to give me pleasure!
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: But, Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: Chère Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: Voyons, Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: I assure you, Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: On the cross, Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: Ah, Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: We implore you, Pupasse!
speaker: the students

utterance: Console yourself, Pupasse! We will help you, Pupasse! Say no more about it! We will help you!
speaker: the students

utterance: Here, Pupasse; here are all our sins. We give them to you; you can have them.
speaker: the students

utterance: Pupasse, ma fille, give me your grammar.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Your last punishment: the rule for irregular verbs. Commence!
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: I know it, Madame Joubert; I know it perfectly, I assure you.
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: Commence!
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Irregular verbs—but I assure you I know it-I know it by heart—
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: Commence, ma fille!
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Irregular verbs-irregular verbs-I know it, Madame Joubert - one moment—
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: give me one word, Madame Joubert; only one word!
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: That-
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Irregular verbs, that—irregular verbs, that
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: See here, Pupasse; you do not know that lesson any more than a cat does
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Yes, I do, Madame Joubert! Yes, I do!
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: Silence!
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: But, Madame Joubert-
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: Will you be silent!
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Yes, Madame Joubert; only”
speaker: Pupasse

utterance: Pupasse, one more word-and-
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Listen, Pupasse, and obey! You go home and learn that lesson. When you know it, you can reënter your class. That is the punishment I have thought of to correct your want of attention.'
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Listen, Pupasse, my child. Go home, study your lesson well. I shall come every evening myself and hear it; and as soon as you know it, I shall fetch you back myself. You know I always keep my word.
speaker: Madame B———
